_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY DOCUMENT-6/21/04



1.    Executive Summary



It is the policy of the Terminal Freezers to adhere to all applicable federal, state and local 

regulations, including methods to safeguard employees and the general public by minimizing or 

eliminating any accidental release of toxic materials. These methods also include detailed 

maintenance, inspection and emergency response plans. 



Terminal Freezers is a cooling business that provides freezing and cooler space for various 

commodities and locally grown produce. There are 6 on site facilities which store and utilize 

Anhydrous Ammonia (CAS # 7664-41-7). Anhydrous Ammonia is described as an irritant and is 

corrosive to skin, eye, respiratory tract and mucous membranes. It may cause burns, eye and lung 

injuries, and could potentially pose a health hazard to Facility staff or public receptors in the 

event of an accidental release of stored material. At this time, the maximum quantity stored is 

45,000 lbs. 



Our general prevention program includes contractor audits for compliance prior to installation, 

regular mechanical integrity checks, written operating procedures, incident investigations, 

regular safety inspections and employee training. This program includes a review of potential 

hazards associated with the regulated chemical at the facility, operational procedures, 

maintenance procedures and employee training. Periodic safety reviews are communicated to 

employees to reduce the possibility of an accidental release. 



Based on Company policy, safety meetings for employees are conducted on a continuing basis 

and ongoing safety improvements are routinely adopted. Additional employee training and 

preventive maintenance programs will be implemented in response to the results of internal 

auditing procedures, process changes, or changes in the regulated substances handled at the 

Facility.



In the last 5 years, there has been one accidental release

on 10-07-03 which did not result in any 

damage to public or environmental receptors. 



To minimize the hazards presented by an accidental release to Facility staff or the public, 

Terminal Freezers has prepared an emergency response plan that coordinates the actions of 

Facility staff with local emergency responders. Further, company supplied safety equipment is 

located in strategic areas and is maintained for staff who are trained in the use of this equipment 

in an emergency response situation. Regular drills are held to maintain a state of readiness. The 

procedures for updating these procedures include an annual review which includes reevaluating 

potential events, such as earthquakes and fires.



The Company is currently revising the current system to augment new technology.



2.    Five-year Accident History



The Company has had one accidental release which occurred at 8:05 A.M. on October 7th, 2003 

in which a 1/4' line was opened by an employee and approximately 137 lbs. of liquid ammonia 

escaped under pressure, which resulted in the hospitalization of the employee. There were no off-

site impacts. The maintenance employee was conducting a check for oil at the bottom of the 

thermosyphon for compressor #7 by opening a valve slightly to see if oil would come out. The 

valve was opened slightly by the employee but nothing came out as the valve was clogged with 

debris. The employee continued to open the valve and pressure cleared the debris, subjecting the 

employee to a stream of liquid ammonia, burning his right forearm and causing irritation to his 

eyes, face, throat and lungs, while he attempted to close the valve. Procedures have been 

changed to include training on correct procedures for checking for oil, positioning valve stems 

facing up for better access and the installation of spring return valves to prevent any re-

occurrence.



3.    Program Requirements



Process Safety Information

SIC/NAIC code: 4222/493120

Name of regu

lated substance: Anhydrous Ammonia

Date of last safety information review/revised: 06/04



Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

*    Date of PHA update: 06/04

*    PHA technique used: "What If" scenario

*    Expected date of completion of recommendations: 06/05

*    Major hazards identified: Toxic release, overpressurization, corrosion, overfilling, 

equipment failure & earthquake.

*    Process controls used: Vents, automatic shutoffs, relief valves, check valves, manual 

shutoffs, alarms and procedures, backup pumps, grounding equipment and purge system.

*    Mitigation systems: Sprinkler systems, fire walls and enclosures. 

*    Monitoring/detection systems: Process area detectors, computerized monitoring system



Changes since last PHA: 

*    Increase in chemical inventory, installation of process controls, installation of process 

detection systems, installation of mitigation systems.



Operating Procedures

Date of most recent review/revision of operating procedures: 06/04



Training

Date of most recent review/revision of training programs: 06/04

Type of training: Class room demonstration, observation & OJT

Type of competency testing: Verbal & results testing

Date of most recent equipment inspection/test: 06/04

t review/revision of contractor safety procedures: 06/99

airplane accident, electrical failure, structural damage, and water damage.

*    Seismic analysis: 6/99



Magnitude or scope of external events considered:

*    Expected date of completion of any changes resulting from PHA: 06/05

*    Major hazards identified: 

*    Process controls in use: Computer control/monitoring - auto shutoff valves

*    Mitigation systems in use: Dump tank

*    Monitoring & detection systems in use: Computer control/monitoring system

*    Changes since last PHA: 06/04

*    Date of most recent field verification that equipment is installed/maintained as designed: 

06/04



Emergency Response Program

Terminal Freezers has a written emergency response plan.

Plan includes specific actions to be taken during release.

Plan includes procedures for informing the public & responding agencies.

Plan includes emergency health care information.

Date of most recent review/update to emergency response plan: 06/04

Date of most recent emergency response training for employees: 06/04

Provide name/telephone number of primary emergency response agency that plan is              

coordinated with: Oxnard Fire Department 

                                           (805) 385-8364 

                                           Steve Mattern, CUPA Coordinator.

List of federal/state emergency plan requirements that stationary source is subject to:

             

*    OSHA Regulations 29 CFR 1910.38, 1910.120

*    State of California EPCRA Regulations
